questions.text: Choose the correct option with respect to the histopathological finding shown below.
questions.solution:
The above image shows intercellular edema involving the stratum spinosum which is suggestive of spongiosis. Spongiosis is the characteristic histopathological feature of acute eczema. 

In contrast, ballooning degeneration is a term that refers to the intracellular edema occurring in the stratum spinosum. This results in acantholysis. Ballooning degeneration is often seen secondary to viral infections like herpes. 

The image below shows ballooning degeneration (intracellular edema is seen).

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of cerebral edema?
questions.solution:
Hypernatermia does not cause cerebral edema but hyponatremia causes it.

Acute cerebral edema is generally seen in hyponatremia due to the following mechanism:

Acute hyponatremia->Increased interstitial pressure -> Shunting of extracellular fluid (ECF) and solutes from interstitial space to CSF and then systemic circulation-> Efflux of Na+, K+, and Cl- from brain cells -> Rapid decrease in tonicity overwhelms regulatory mechanisms -> Acute hyponatremic encephalopathy -> Acute cerebral edema.

  • Lead and Cerebral Edema: Toxic effects of systemic lead exposure manifest in the CNS generally as acute encephalopathy in children and polyneuropathy in adults. Cerebral edema, especially of the white matter is most commonly seen in children with lead intoxication.
  • Liver Failure and Cerebral Edema: Acute liver failure commonly causes brain edema, seizures, and agitation. Brain edema has been linked to persistent hyperammonemia in acute liver failure. Brain edema is one of the leading causes of mortality in acute liver failure.
  • High-Altitude Cerebral Edema (HACE): HACE is a condition in the spectrum of altitude-related neurologic disorders that occurs in rapid ascent. It is an encephalopathy that rapidly causes ataxia and altered consciousness with diffuse cerebral involvement but without focal neurological deficits.

questions.text: Kumar presented with massive proteinuria and peripheral oedema. Which among the following conditions is the most likely diagnosis, based on the slide obtained after renal biopsy?
questions.solution:
The slide shows a normal glomerulus which rules out the other diagnosis. Hence, the most likely diagnosis is minimal change disease as it has a normal appearance on light microscopy.

Minimal change disease shows effacement of podocyte foot processes on electron microscopy. This finding can also be seen in membranous nephropathy and focal segmental glomerulosclerosis.

Other options:

Option A: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis shows focal and segmental sclerosis of glomeruli and hyalinosis of the capillary wall.

Option C: Membranous nephropathy shows diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall without cellular proliferation (A) and irregular spikes projecting from the basement membrane best seen with silver stains (B).

Option D: Kimmelstiel-Wilson disease or nodular glomerulosclerosis occurs in diabetics and shows ovoid or spherical PAS positive nodules with diffuse mesangial sclerosis and capillary basement membrane thickening.

questions.text: Which of the following is not one of the mechanisms involved in the pathogenesis of edema?
questions.solution:
Increased plasma colloid osmotic pressure is not one of the mechanisms in the pathogenesis of edema. 

Edema is the accumulation of tissue fluid in the extracellular space, resulting from hemodynamic changes in the body. Normally, the outward hydrostatic pressure in the blood vessels is balanced by the inward pull of the colloid osmotic pressure exerted by plasma proteins. Any remaining fluid in the interstitial space is usually drained by the lymphatics into the thoracic duct, and thereby, back into the bloodstream. 

Edema results when there is an abnormality in any of these balancing forces. In heart failure, there is increased hydrostatic pressure in the venous system due to the inability of the heart to pump blood. This can result in edema which usually begins in the lower extremities.

In liver disease, there is a failure to synthesize adequate amounts of plasma proteins. On the other hand, in nephrotic disease of the kidney, there is excessive excretion of plasma proteins. Both of these conditions can result in decreased plasma colloid osmotic pressure. This normally acts as an inward pull on fluid from the interstitial spaces into the blood vessels.

Another mechanism of edema is in the setting of acute inflammation when there is increased vessel permeability, leading to fluid leaks into the interstitium.

Lymphatic obstruction due to infection or malignant infiltration can stop the normal tissue fluid drainage which results in fluid accumulation.

Renal failure is another cause of edema, which occurs due to the retention of sodium and water in large amounts, which ultimately increase the hydrostatic pressure within the vessels as mentioned above. 

Related Pearl: Edema: Key Points

Edema: Key Points

Edema is the result of the movement of fluid from the vasculature into the interstitial spaces; the fluid may be protein-poor (transudate) or protein-rich (exudate).

Causes:

  • Increased hydrostatic pressure (e.g., heart failure)
  • Decreased colloid osmotic pressure caused by reduced plasma albumin, either due to decreased synthesis (e.g., liver disease, protein malnutrition) or to increased loss (e.g., nephrotic syndrome)
  • Increased vascular permeability (e.g., inflammation), which is usually localized but may occur throughout the body in severe systemic inflammatory states such as sepsis
  • Lymphatic obstruction (e.g., infection or neoplasia)
  • Sodium and water retention (e.g., renal failure)

questions.text:
Match the given conditions with the mechanism causing edema in them.
Conditions Mechanism
1. Lymphatic blockage a. Increase in capillary pressure
2. Nephrotic syndrome b. Increase in capillary permeability
3. Heart failure c. Increase in interstitial oncotic pressure
4. Infections d. Decrease in capillary osmotic pressure
5. Liver failure
questions.solution:
The correctly matched conditions and mechanisms causing edema are: 1- c, 2- d, 3- a, 4- b, 5- d

Conditions Mechanism
1. Lymphatic blockage c. Increase in interstitial oncotic pressure
2. Nephrotic syndrome d. Decrease in capillary osmotic pressure
3. Heart failure a. Increase in capillary pressure
4. Infections b. Increase in capillary permeability
5. Liver failure d. Decrease in plasma proteins

Option 1: The lymphatic system returns small amounts of proteins and fluid that leak into the interstitium back to circulation. In case of lymphatic blockage, these proteins and fluids cannot be cleared and instead accumulate in the interstitium. This fluid accumulation leads to edema. The accumulating proteins increase the interstitial colloidal osmotic pressure and draw more fluid into the interstitium.

Options 2 and 5: In nephrotic syndrome, there is a loss of proteins in the urine while in liver cirrhosis there is failure of production of proteins. Both of these conditions result in decreased plasma proteins. Plasma proteins are responsible for the capillary colloidal osmotic pressure that causes the osmosis of fluid into the capillary. A decrease in the capillary oncotic pressure causes more fluid to move into the interstitium, causing edema. 

Option 3: In heart failure, there is an inability of the heart to pump out the blood. This pump inefficiency causes back pressure and an increase in venous and capillary pressure. This increase in capillary hydrostatic pressure forces the fluid out of the capillary and causes edema.

Option 4: Infections cause inflammation and membrane damage. This leads to increased capillary permeability and fluid leaks into the interstitium causing edema.

questions.text: Cardiac edema and neuropathy are seen in which of the following vitamin deficiencies?
questions.solution:
Cardiac edema and neuropathy are associated with the deficiency of thiamine (vitamin B1). 

Early symptoms of thiamine deficiency include peripheral neuropathy, irritability, loss of deep tendon reflexes, and proprioception. As the disease progresses, increased intracranial pressure, meningismus, and coma develop.

Wet beriberi (cardiac) is associated with tachycardia, cardiomegaly, cardiac failure, and edema. It is commonly seen in the refugee camps where people consume polished rice based monotonous diets. Diagnosis of thiamine deficiency can be established by erythrocyte transketolase activity assessment.

Dry beriberi is associated with neurological deficits such as optic atrophy, ataxia, and irritability.

Complications include lactic acidosis and Wernicke encephalopathy.

questions.text: A term baby is noted to have a diffuse edematous swelling on the scalp immediately after birth. He was delivered by normal vaginal delivery with vertex presentation. The most likely site of the swelling noted in this baby would be:
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the baby has developed a diffuse edematous swelling on the scalp immediately after birth suggestive of caput succedaneum. The most likely site of this swelling is represented by the structure marked as 1 in the image.

1- Caput succedaneum is a diffuse edematous collection in the soft tissues of the scalp with vertex presentation. It can extend across skull sutures and disappears within the first week of life.

2- Cephalohematoma is a subperiosteal hemorrhage. It occurs following instrumental delivery which results in rupture of emissary veins of the skull. It does not cross suture lines. The swelling appears only several hours after birth. They are resorbed within two weeks to 3 months, depending on their size.

3- Subgaleal hemorrhage is a collection of blood under the aponeurosis of the scalp. It occurs as a result of ventouse deliveries due to tears of the emissary veins which connect to the dural venous sinuses. It can occur in hereditary coagulopathies and is associated with skull fractures.

4- Epidural hemorrhage is usually traumatic in origin. These are associated with cephalo-pelvic disproportion, prolonged labor, breech, precipitous labors, or as a result of mechanical assistance in labor. Majority resolve with no intervention.

The image given below shows various birth injuries to the head.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented with bilateral pedal edema. Urine examination showed proteinuria. Histopathology of the kidney was as shown below. It was found PAS positive. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and histopathology image showing acellular periodic acid Schiff (PAS)-positive nodules are suggestive of Kimmelstiel–Wilson disease. It occurs in patients with diabetic nephropathy.

The following renal lesions are encountered in diabetic nephropathy:

  • Glomerular lesions - Capillary basement membrane thickening, diffuse mesangial sclerosis, nodular glomerulosclerosis /Kimmelstiel–Wilson disease- intercapillary glomerulosclerosis.
  • Renal vascular lesions - hyaline arteriolosclerosis.
  • Pyelonephritis - necrotizing papillitis.

Other options:

Option A: In Renal amyloidosis, glomerular deposits appear as thickenings of the mesangial matrix, forming interlacing broad ribbons of amyloid.

Option B: In focal segmental glomerulosclerosis, there is focal and segmental hyalinosis and sclerosis of the capillary wall with lipid droplets in the sclerosed area.

Option D: In lupus nephritis, immune complex deposits are seen in the mesangium or along the entire basement membrane (wire loop lesions), with mesangial cell proliferation.

questions.text: A body of a 30-year-old man is retrieved from the local river and subjected to autopsy. His family accuses his friend of murdering him by pushing him into the river after making him unconscious by hitting his head with a wooden stick. Which autopsy finding will favor the family's accusation?
questions.solution:
The finding of edema aquosum in the autopsy will favor the family's accusation. Edema aquosum occurs when the victim is alive but unconscious at the time of the drowning. This is mere flooding of the lungs with the water without the formation of froth as respiratory efforts are absent.

Autopsy findings in drowning:

  • Froth - The presence of copious amounts of fine, shaving-lather-like froth at the mouth and the nostrils is the most characteristic finding of antemortem drowning. It is caused by the vigorous agitation of the tracheal and bronchial mucous secretions, edema fluid, and alveolar surfactant during respiratory efforts. 
  • Cutis anserina - The contraction of the erector pilorum muscles causes puckering and a grainy appearance of the skin. This resembles goose skin; hence, it is called cutis anserina.
  • Washerwoman’s hand - Maceration of the skin on the palms and soles gives a wrinkled, sodden, and bleached appearance due to submersion.
  • Cadaveric spasm - Gravel, weed, soil, grass, etc. is firmly held in the clenched hands due to cadaveric spasm. This is a vital sign of antemortem drowning. The material also indicates the place of submersion.
  • Rigor mortis - This appears early in cases of a violent antemortem struggle.
  • Face - It is bloated and discolored, with cyanosis.
  • Eyes - Conjunctiva are suffused and pupils dilated.
  • Tongue - It may be swollen and protruded.
  • Antemortem injuries - These may be sustained by striking objects, such as rocks, during the fall into the water body. Examination for such injuries must be performed only after the body is dry.
  • Lungs - They appear voluminous and distended show ballooning. The cut section will exude copious amounts of frothy, bloodstained fluid.
  • Larynx, trachea, and bronchioles - The presence of sand, silt, and aquatic vegetation in the trachea and lower respiratory tract are characteristic findings of antemortem drowning.
  • Heart and blood vessels- Gettler test can be done to estimate the chloride content in the right and left sides of the heart to differentiate between freshwater and saltwater drowning. 
  • Diatom test- Diatoms are microscopic algae. Their presence in the organs, particularly in the bone marrow, is suggestive of antemortem drowning.
  • Stomach and small intestines- These organs may contain water in some cases. Water present in the small intestine is positive evidence of death by drowning.
  • Middle ear - The presence of water in the middle ear is highly suggestive of antemortem drowning.
  • Brain - It is congested, and edematous, with loss of gray-white junction.

Other options:

Option B: Hydrostatic lung, is seen in postmortem drowning. When a dead body is thrown into the water, water passes into the lungs due to hydrostatic pressure. 

Option C: Emphysema aquosum - This is seen in cases when the victim is alive and conscious. Overinflation of the lungs in drowning is known as emphysema aquosum. It is one of the most valuable positive signs of drowning. The edema fluid in the bronchi blocks the passive collapse that normally occurs at death. Hence, the lungs are held in the inspiratory position. The impression of the ribs on this overinflated lung leaves visible and palpable grooves on the lateral surface. 

Option D: Diatom test- Diatoms are microscopic algae. Their presence in the organs, particularly in the bone marrow, is suggestive of antemortem drowning. In postmortem drowning, diatoms do not spread to distant organs because of the absence of circulation and are limited to the lungs.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with hoarseness and a low-pitched voice. She is a singer and a known smoker. Her laryngoscopy findings are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The laryngoscopy findings show diffuse bilateral edema of the vocal folds suggestive of Reinke's edema.

It occurs due to edema of the subepithelial space (Reinke’s space) of the vocal cords in the glottis.

Key clinical features

  • History of smoking and/or voice abuse.
  • Hoarseness is the most common symptom.
  • Patients use false cords for voice production and this gives them a low-pitched and rough voice.

On indirect laryngoscopy, both vocal cords show diffuse symmetrical swellings. They appear as fusiform swellings with a pale translucent look. Ventricular bands may appear hyperemic and hypertrophic and may hide the view of the true cords.

Treatment

  • Voice rest and cessation of smoking
  • Decortication of the vocal cords, i.e. removal of a strip of epithelium
  • Speech therapy for proper voice production.

Other options

Option B: Laryngeal papilloma/ squamous papilloma are benign tumors of the larynx caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV type 6 and 11). They occur in children (juvenile papillomatosis) as well as adults. Patients present with hoarseness, dyspnea or stridor.

Laryngoscopy shows pinkish to white “grape-like” projections that can be sessile or pedunculate with a visible central vascular core. 

The image below shows laryngeal papilloma. 

Option C: A Vocal polyp is caused by vocal abuse or misuses such as sudden shouting resulting in hemorrhage and submucosal edema. It presents with hoarseness and diplophonia. In case of a large polyp, dyspnea, stridor or choking may occur.

On indirect laryngoscopy, they appear as soft, smooth, mobile, and pedunculated mass arising from the free edge of the vocal cord at the junction between anterior one-third and posterior two-third of the vocal cord. They are mostly unilateral.

Treatment is by surgical excision followed by speech therapy.

The image below shows a vocal polyp.

Option D: Vocal nodules (Singer's or Screamer's nodes) are also caused by vocal abuse or misuse. It most commonly affects teachers, actors, singers, vendors, and talkative school children. Patients complain of hoarseness, vocal fatigue, and neck pain during prolonged talking.

On indirect laryngoscopy, they appear as a greyish or white pin-head-sized mass arising from the free edge of the vocal cord at the junction between anterior one-third and posterior two-third of the vocal cord. They are mostly symmetrical (bilateral).

Small vocal nodules are treated conservatively with speech therapy. Large ones are treated by surgical excision followed by speech therapy.

The image below shows symmetrical vocal nodules.

questions.text: A young female presents with sudden onset severe pain in the left eye after watching a movie. She rushes to the hospital as there is a progressive loss of vision. She has ciliary injection and a shallow anterior chamber. The pupil is semi dilated and the cornea appears oedematous. What is the procedure of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of sudden onset severe pain in the eye, progressive loss of vision, shallow anterior chamber, semi-dilated pupil, and edematous cornea is suggestive of acute angle-closure glaucoma. Laser iridotomy is the procedure of choice especially in emergency situations. 

The attack may have been precipitated by pupillary dilation, which may result from activities such as going to a movie theater. Laser iridotomy re-establishes the communication between the posterior and anterior chamber, bypassing the pupillary block; hence, it immediately relieves crowding of the angle.

Various surgical and laser modalities used in glaucoma:

Angle-closure glaucoma: 

  • Laser iridotomy by Nd:Yag along with prophylactic iridotomy of the other eye → Treatment of choice.
  • Trabeculectomy → Filtration surgery

Congenital glaucoma: 

  • Goniotomy
  • Trabeculotomy

Primary open-angle glaucoma:

  • Laser trabeculoplasty: Argon or diode (if not controlled medications)
  • Trabeculectomy: Filtration surgery (if not controlled medications)

Absolute glaucoma:

  • Cyclocryotherapy
  • Nd:Yag lasercyclo destruction

questions.text: Which vitamin, when infused in supraphysiological doses, causes macular edema and macular cysts?
questions.solution:
Macular cysts and edema may develop in patients due to the infusion of supraphysiological doses of vitamin B3 (niacin toxicity).

The toxic effects of niacin include:

  • Flushing associated with skin dryness, itching, paresthesia, and headache is seen. These effects may be seen with even a low dose of 30mg/day. Pre-medication with aspirin alleviates these symptoms as these symptoms are mediated by prostaglandins.
  • Macular edema and macular cysts
  • Nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain.
  • Hepatic toxicity presents as jaundice with elevated AST and ALT levels.
  • Fulminant hepatitis requiring liver transplantation.
  • Glucose intolerance
  • Hyperuricemia

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of papilledema?
questions.solution:
Disruption of neurofilaments is not a feature of papilledema.

Papilledema is the swelling of the optic nerve head secondary to raised intracranial pressure (ICP).

"Disc swelling" and "disc edema" are non-specific terms that include papilledema but also indicate a disc swollen from other causes.

All patients with papilledema should be suspected of harboring an intracranial mass.

Features of papilledema:

  • Raised ICP
  • Edema of the optic nerve head
    • Blockage of axoplasmic flow
    • Axonal swelling
    • Collection of extracellular fluid
  • Painless progressive loss of vision
  • Enlargement of the blind spot
  • Color vision, visual acuity, and pupillary reaction are normal, until optic atrophy sets in.

questions.text: An adult presents with massive proteinuria, edema, and hematuria. The biopsy image is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features and biopsy image showing uniform, diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall are suggestive of membranous glomerulonephritis.

Membranous nephropathy is a chronic immune complex–mediated disease characterized by diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall due to the accumulation of deposits containing Ig. Immunofluorescence microscopy demonstrates that the granular deposits contain both immunoglobulins and complement.

It will present as nephrotic syndrome with massive proteinuria, generalized edema, hyperlipidemia, and lipiduria. Most of the cases are primary. Some of the secondary causes include

  • Drugs (penicillamine, captopril, NSAIDs, gold),
  • Malignant tumors- Lung, colon, and melanoma
  • SLE
  • Infections -Chronic Hep B, Hep C, syphilis
  • Autoimmune disorders. 

In RPGN Type I and Goodpasture syndrome, a characteristic linear pattern is observed on immunofluorescence which is a classic anti-GBM disease. Minimal Change disease has negative immunofluorescence.

questions.text: Peripheral edema seen with the use of calcium channel blockers is primarily due to which of the following mechanisms?

choices.text: Reduced glomerular filtration rate and renal blood flow
Increased hydrostatic pressure in the capillaries of lower extremeties
Decreased oncotic pressure due to loss of plasma proteins in urine
Precapillary constriction and post capillary dilation

questions.solution:
Calcium channel blockers induced peripheral edema is most likely due to increased hydrostatic pressure in the capillaries of the lower extremities.

The increased hydrostatic pressure occurs due to precapillary dilation and reflex postcapillary constriction.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with complaints of dysphagia. She also says that her hands and feet turn cold and blue when she goes to visit her daughter who lives in a hill station. Her examination findings are as given in the image. What is the earliest cutaneous manifestation that can be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of systemic sclerosis. The earliest cutaneous manifestations in systemic sclerosis are non-pitting edema and puffiness of the fingers, hands, and face. 

The image shows a woman with mask-like facies with stretched, shiny skin, and loss of normal facial lines, microstomia, and resorption of distal phalanges of the fingers. The clinical history describes Raynaud's phenomenon (hands and feet turn cold and blue in cold climate) and hence, the probable diagnosis is systemic sclerosis.

Systemic sclerosis is an autoimmune rheumatic disease in which there is a 4: 1 female predominance.

Cutaneous features:

  • Hands and feet - Raynaud's phenomenon, non-pitting edema, painful ulcerations which heal with pitted scars, sclerodactyly, contractures, loss of sweat glands, bone resorption.
  • Face - periorbital edema, mask-like facies, telangiectasia, and diffuse hyperpigmentation.
  • Trunk - firm, shiny, and thickened skin.
  • Reduced hair growth is seen.

Systemic features:

  • GIT- dysphagia, GERD, diminished peristalsis, malabsorption
  • Lungs- pulmonary fibrosis and alveolitis
  • Heart- cardiac conduction defects, heart failure
  • Kidney- uremia, malignant hypertension
  • Musculoskeletal- weakness, carpal tunnel syndrome.

Using modified Rodnan skin score (MRSS). the degree of skin sclerosis is scored from 0 to 3 by manual palpation at 17 different body sites. The maximum score that can be attained is 51. This method has been shown to correlate with skin biopsy thickness, disease severity, and long‐term outcome of the disease.

The scoring of each skin region is determined by skin thickness and tethering:
0 = Normal
1 = Possible thickening
2 = Unable to pinch the skin
3 = Unable to move the skin (which is fixed to deeper tissues)

This modified score does not include the assessment of the neck and back. If these areas are included, the maximum attainable score increases to 57.

questions.text: A  post-cataract surgery patient came with complaints of blurring of vision for the past 2 weeks. His cataract surgery was done 3 months back. His optical coherence tomography (OCT) image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a post-cataract surgery patient presenting with a blurring of vision and an OCT image showing intraretinal cystoid spaces is suggestive of cystoid macular edema (CME).

Common causes of CME include previous cataract surgery, uveitis, central retinal vein occlusions, diabetic retinopathy, retinitis pigmentosa, and retinopathy of prematurity, and topical prostaglandins. Cystoid macular edema in post-cataract surgery patients is termed as Irvine-Gass syndrome. 

In CME, OCT shows foveal depression, intraretinal cystoid spaces, and retinal thickening.

CME occurs due to a break in the inner and outer blood-retinal barrier. Due to retinal vessel leak fluid or exudate comes out and forms cystic space in the central retina. Mostly it gets accumulated in the outer plexiform (Henle's layer) and inner nuclear layers of the retina. 

On fundoscopy, the multiple cystoid oval spaces in CME appear as a  "honeycomb appearance".

In Fundus fluorescein angiography fluid accumulation in outer plexiform, layer shows a characteristic flower petal pattern (petaloid appearance) as shown below:

Topical antiprostaglandins and steroids are used in the management of CME. 

Other options:

Option B: Macular hole is the partial or full-thickness hole in the neurosensory retina. An OCT image of a full-thickness macular hole is shown below:

Option C: Central serous retinopathy is the spontaneous serous detachment of the neuroretina in the macular region with or without retinal pigment epithelium detachment.

Due to the altered permeability of the choroidal vascular system, there is an increase in the tissue hydrostatic pressure in the choroid. This causes a breach in the outer blood-retinal barrier. Leakage of fluid across this area causes detachment of the neurosensory retina. 

An OCT of central serous retinopathy showing neurosensory retinal detachment from the retinal pigment epithelium is given below:

Option D: Senile macular degeneration also known as age-related macular degeneration is a leading cause of blindness in the old age population. Extracellular deposits called drusens are deposited between retinal pigment epithelium and brush membrane.

In OCT drusens can be seen as hyperreflective irregular nodules and severe disruption of the external limiting membrane of the retina from choroid can be seen.

questions.text: A 50-year-old diabetic man, presented with pain, redness and swelling of his left leg as shown in the image below.  Aspiration of the edema fluid revealed a high protein concentration. Which of the following is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the image showing the affected lower limb with diffuse borders, erythema, and edema, are suggestive of cellulitis.

Edema fluid showing a high protein concentration is also characteristic of cellulitis. It is typically lower in venous thrombosis.

Cellulitis is a painful, diffuse infection of the dermis and the subcutaneous tissue. It is characterized by poorly demarcated areas of marked edema, dilated superficial capillaries, and extravasation of red blood cells and inflammatory cells into the dermis.

The image given below shows poorly demarcated areas of edema and erythema in cellulitis.

The common pathogens involved are:

  • Group A streptococci: Major causative organism
  • Staphylococcus aureus: Occasional cause of cellulitis, commonly causes erysipelas
  • Haemophilus influenzae type b: Common cause of facial cellulitis in children less than 2 years old
  • Groups B and G streptococci: In case of a venous or lymphatic compromise

Lower limbs are the commonest site of cellulitis and any wound, including tinea pedis or bacterial infection, is a possible site of entry. The face is the next common site of infection.

Clinical features include:

  • Constitutional symptoms like fever and malaise
  • Local symptoms like erythema, heat, swelling, and tenderness

In cellulitis, the edge of the lesion is diffuse, while in erysipelas, the edge of the lesion is well demarcated and raised

The given image shows how the edges of the lesion in cellulitis are diffuse.

Specimens for bacteriological examination and cultures can be taken from vesicle fluid or eroded or ulcerated surfaces. In the case of facial infections, the nose, throat, conjunctiva and sinuses should be tested for pathogens. Soluble streptococcal antigens may be identified in serology.

Initial treatment should cover streptococci and H. influenzae, in young children. Cellulitis usually settles over 1–2 weeks with the appropriate systemic antibiotics.

Related Pearl: Skin and soft tissue lesions caused by Streptococcus

Streptococcus causes a variety of skin and soft tissue infections. These include:

a. Impetigo- Infection of superficial layers of the skin. It presents as superficial vesicles which break down and are then encrusted by honey-colored scab. It usually occurs in children.

The given image shows impetigo:

 

b. Erysipelas-

  • Infection of the superficial epidermis.
    • It presents as an erythematous raised lesion with sharply demarcated edges that differentiate it from the surrounding skin.
      • The given image shows erysipelas- note the clear demarcation at the nasolabial folds seen in facial erysipelas.

 

c. Cellulitis- Infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue. It presents with erythema and edema. It can be differentiated from erysipelas by - i. Erysipelas is a raised lesion whereas cellulitis is not, ii. Cellulitis is poorly demarcated from the surrounding skin whereas erysipelas is clearly demarcated.

The given image shows cellulitis:

 

d. Necrotizing fasciitis- Infection involving the fascial planes. It presents with dark areas of necrosis, erythema, and edema.

The given image shows necrotizing fasciitis with areas of erythema and necrosis:

 

d. Myositis and myonecrosis- Infection of the muscle.

The given image shows necrotizing myositis:

Related Pearl: Skin and soft tissue lesions caused by Staphylococcus

Staphylococcus causes a variety of skin and soft tissue infections. These include:

a. Furuncle/boil- Infection of the hair follicle.

The given image shows a furuncle:

 

b. Carbuncle: A cluster of several furuncles:

The given image shows a carbuncle:

 

c. Bullous impetigo: Results in large blisters called bullae, usually seen in areas with skin folds such as armpits, groin, buttocks, etc.

The given image shows ruptured bullous impetigo:

 

d. Cellulitis: It is a rapidly spreading infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue, usually associated with wounds, incisions, burns, etc.

The given image shows cellulitis following an abrasion. The red streaks indicate the involvement of the lymphatics:

 

e. Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome: Caused by exfoliating toxin that causes peeling of the skin.

The given image shows SSSS:

 

Note: The conditions shown above are most commonly caused by Staphylococcus. It is important to remember that they may also be caused by other bacteria. Cellulitis is more commonly caused by Streptococcus.
